name: Marty Robbins "Ballad of the Alamo" Online Trivia | Music | 10 Questions

questions.text: According to Marty Robbins in which part of Texas did the action at the Alamo take place?
questions.explanation:
southern.

	Everything happened in the town of San Antone which was in the territory disputed with Mexico. That's where the remains of the fortress can still be seen.

questions.text: According to Marty Robbins which musical instrument can still sometimes be heard?
questions.explanation:
a bugle.

	It is the "ghostly bugle" which is summoning them to the roll-call. It's not quite clear what you hear as they answer - perhaps the sound of their feet as they march to the point of assembly.

questions.text: What is the rank of Travis who commanded the volunteers at the Alamo?
questions.explanation:
Colonel.

	Huston ordered Colonel Travis to "fortify the Alamo". The purpose was apparently to delay the Mexicans until Huston could gather together an army big enough to be effective.

questions.text: Which two legendary heroes were amongst the volunteers at the Alamo?
questions.explanation:
Davy Crockett and Jim Bowie.

	According to the words of the song,  "Well, the men came from Texas   And from old Tennessee." However, a study of the list of names reveals that quite a few were also from England, Scotland and Ireland.

questions.text: What was the name and rank of Travis' second in command?
questions.explanation:
Captain Dickinson.

	Including the Mexican general, Santa Anna, "Captain Dickinson" was one of only six names mentioned in the song - they were Santa Anna, Huston, Travis, Dickinson, Bowie and Crockett.

questions.text:
Complete the following lines: "Indian scouts with squirrel guns
                               Men with ___________"
questions.explanation:
muzzle-loaders.

	The men defending "The Alamo" could fire one shot and then had to set about the complicated business of reloading via the muzzle part of the rifle. Thus it was essential that the officers controlled very carefully just when ranks of soldiers fired their rifles.

questions.text: Of the 185 men who had volunteered not one took the chance to leave by stepping over Travis's line drawn in the sand. According to the song what did he draw it with?
options: the hilt of the flagpole carrying the Texan flag
the butt of a squirrel gun
questions.explanation:
his army sabre.

	As an officer Travis would carry a sabre. It was more normal to volunteer by stepping forward over a line i.e. to put yourself forward. Either way all the volunteers stayed to fight.

questions.text: What colour was the horse that Santa Anna was riding?
questions.explanation:
black.

	The song says, "A horse that was black as the night."  The picture painted is a dramatic one. Santa Anna arrives with his army "In the dawn's golden light". His prancing horse must cut a sinister and menacing figure.

questions.text: When the volunteers refuse to surrender and fire a shell at him Santa Anna orders "Deguello". What does this mean?
questions.correct: A bugle message telling his troops to spare none of the enemy.
options: A bugle message telling his troops to surround the Alamo.
A bugle message telling his troops to dismount.
A bugle message telling his troops to attack at once.
questions.explanation:
A bugle message telling his troops to spare none of the enemy.

	The idea is that Santa Anna is infuriated that so few men are refusing to surrender to his large army. Thus he loses his temper and orders that "Every one will be put to the sword."  On the fatal final third charge, "Santa Anna breached the wall          And he killed 'em one and all."

questions.text: How does the cowboy of today show his respect for the men of the Alamo?
questions.correct: He takes off his hat to them.
options: He dismounts from his pinto and says a prayer.
He plants flowers by the side of the fortress.
He steers his horse around and not over the graves.
questions.explanation:
He takes off his hat to them.

	"And he takes his hat off slowly... To the men of Alamo." He is remembering the way in which 185 men held off 5,000 for thirteen days back in the year 1836.
